data.value: Bessel/Thomson digital and analog filter design.
Design an Nth-order digital or analog Bessel filter and return the filter coefficients.
The order of the filter.
A scalar or length-2 sequence giving the critical frequencies (defined by the
parameter). For analog filters,
is an angular frequency (e.g., rad/s).
For digital filters,
are in the same units as
.  By default,
is 2 half-cycles/sample, so these are normalized from 0 to 1, where 1 is the Nyquist frequency. (
is thus in half-cycles / sample.)
The type of filter.  Default is 'lowpass'.
When True, return an analog filter, otherwise a digital filter is returned. (See Notes.)
Type of output:  numerator/denominator ('ba'), pole-zero ('zpk'), or second-order sections ('sos'). Default is 'ba'.
Critical frequency normalization:
The filter is normalized such that the phase response reaches its     midpoint at angular (e.g. rad/s) frequency
. This happens for     both low-pass and high-pass filters, so this is the     "phase-matched" case.
The magnitude response asymptotes are the same as a Butterworth     filter of the same order with a cutoff of
This is the default, and matches MATLAB's implementation.
The filter is normalized such that the group delay in the passband     is 1/
(e.g., seconds). This is the "natural" type obtained by     solving Bessel polynomials.
The filter is normalized such that the gain magnitude is -3 dB at     angular frequency
The sampling frequency of the digital system.
Numerator (
) and denominator (
) polynomials of the IIR filter. Only returned if
Zeros, poles, and system gain of the IIR filter transfer function.  Only returned if
Second-order sections representation of the IIR filter. Only returned if
Also known as a Thomson filter, the analog Bessel filter has maximally flat group delay and maximally linear phase response, with very little ringing in the step response. [1]_

The Bessel is inherently an analog filter. This function generates digital Bessel filters using the bilinear transform, which does not preserve the phase response of the analog filter. As such, it is only approximately correct at frequencies below about fs/4. To get maximally-flat group delay at higher frequencies, the analog Bessel filter must be transformed using phase-preserving techniques.
See
for implementation details and references.
The
output parameter was added in 0.16.0.
Plot the phase-normalized frequency response, showing the relationship to the Butterworth's cutoff frequency (green):
fig-scipy.signal.filter_design.bessel-1.png
and the phase midpoint:
fig-scipy.signal.filter_design.bessel-2.png
Plot the magnitude-normalized frequency response, showing the -3 dB cutoff:
fig-scipy.signal.filter_design.bessel-3.png
Plot the delay-normalized filter, showing the maximally-flat group delay at 0.1 seconds:
fig-scipy.signal.filter_design.bessel-4.png

signature: bessel(N, Wn, btype='low', analog=False, output='ba', norm='phase', fs=None)
references: .. [1] Thomson, W.E., "Delay Networks having Maximally Flat Frequency
Characteristics", Proceedings of the Institution of Electrical
Engineers, Part III, November 1949, Vol. 96, No. 44, pp. 487-490.
